Name: Linear Programming
Description: Optimize a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints. The decision variables are continuous.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: An LP problem where some or all decision variables are restricted to integer values. Adds combinatorial complexity.
Solvability: NP-Hard in general. Solution time grows exponentially with number of integer variables.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: Optimize a quadratic objective function subject to linear constraints. A common subclass is convex QP.
Solvability: Convex QP is efficiently solvable (P). Non-convex QP is generally NP-Hard.

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: Optimize a nonlinear objective function subject to nonlinear constraints. The most general form.
Solvability: Extremely difficult. Often only local optima can be found for non-convex problems. Convex NLPs are solvable.

Name: Constraint Programming
Description: Model problems with decision variables and constraints
Solvability: but focus is on feasibility and logical constraints
Example: not just an objective function. Variables can be non-numeric.
Appearances: Powerful for feasibility problems. Solution methods (constraint propagation) are very different from MILP.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: Optimization under uncertainty. Parameters are random variables with known probability distributions. The objective often involves an expectation.
Solvability: Computationally intensive. Requires knowledge of the underlying probability distribution or many samples.

Name: Robust Optimization
Description: Optimization under uncertainty where parameters are unknown but bounded within a defined uncertainty set. Aims for solutions that are feasible for all realizations in the set.
Solvability: Computationally tractable for many problem classes (often reformulated as LP

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: A broad field focused on finding optimal solutions from a finite set of discrete objects. Problems are defined on graphs
column8: Generally NP-Hard. Requires specialized algorithms (exact and heuristic).

Name: Dynamic Programming
Solvability: not a problem type. It breaks a complex problem into simpler subproblems and solves them recursively. Used for optimal decision-making over time.
Example: Efficient for problems with optimal substructure and overlapping subproblems. "Curse of dimensionality" is a major limitation.

Name: Semidefinite Programming
Description: A generalization of LP where the solution is a positive semidefinite matrix. Used in approximations for hard problems and in control theory.
